assail.meaning_1: verb: attack in speech or writing
assail.sentence_1: In the weekly paper, the editor assailed the governor for wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in public projects that quickly failed.

fickle.meaning_1: adjective: liable to sudden unpredictable change, esp. in affections or attachments
fickle.sentence_1: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.

inadvertent.meaning_1: adjective: happening by chance or unexpectedly or unintentionally
inadvertent.sentence_1: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led to its repeal.

impeccable.sentence_1: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

grovel.sentence_1: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire him.

hamstrung.sentence_1: The FBI has made so many restrictions on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

tawdry.meaning_1: adjective: tastelessly showy; cheap and shoddy
tawdry.sentence_1: Carol expected to find New York City magical, the way so many movies had portrayed it, but she was surprised how often tawdry displays took the place of genuine elegance.

precedent.meaning_1: noun: an example that is used to justify similar occurrences at a later time
precedent.sentence_1: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.

euphoria.meaning_1: noun: a feeling of great (usually exaggerated) elation
euphoria.sentence_1: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.

detrimental.meaning_1: adjective: (sometimes followed by "to") causing harm or injury
detrimental.sentence_1: Many know that smoking is detrimental to your health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.

vacuous.meaning_1: adjective: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance
vacuous.sentence_1: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.

facetious.sentence_1: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex education class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.

urbane.meaning_1: adjective: showing a high degree of refinement and the assurance that comes from wide social experience
urbane.sentence_1: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophisticate spy James Bond.

lucid.meaning_1: adjective: (of language) transparently clear; easily understandable
lucid.sentence_1: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

elaborate.sentence_2: Most high school physics teachers find themselves elaborating the same point over and over again, since many concepts confuse students.
elaborate.sentence_1: Thomas, on returning from Morocco, replaced his dirty gray carpet with an elaborate one he'd brought back with him.
elaborate.meaning_1: adjective: marked by complexity and richness of detail

benign.sentence_2: The tumor located in your ear lobe seems to be benign and should not cause you any trouble.
benign.meaning_2: adjective: (medicine) not dangerous to health; not recurrent or progressive
benign.sentence_1: I remember my grandfather's face was wrinkled, benign, and calm.

sentimental.meaning_1: adjective: effusively or insincerely emotional, especially in art, music, and literature
sentimental.sentence_1: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas—overly sentimental.

irresolute.meaning_1: adjective: uncertain how to act or proceed
irresolute.sentence_1: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to the camp.

augment.sentence_1: Ideally, the restaurant's augmented menu will expand its clientele and increase its profits.

genial.sentence_1: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

egotist.meaning_1: noun: a conceited and self-centered person
egotist.sentence_1: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.

surly.meaning_1: adjective: inclined to anger or bad feelings with overtones of menace
surly.sentence_1: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly, unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.

smattering.meaning_1: noun: a slight or superficial understanding of a subject; a small amount of something
smattering.sentence_1: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.

conducive.meaning_1: adjective: making a situation or outcome more likely to happen
conducive.sentence_1: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.

whimsical.meaning_1: adjective: determined by impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
whimsical.sentence_1: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.

empathetic.meaning_1: adjective: showing understanding and ready comprehension of other peoples' states and emotions
empathetic.sentence_1: Most discrimination and hatred is based on a lack of empathetic awareness of people that have the same aspirations and fears.

commendable.sentence_1: The efforts of the firefighters running into the burning building were commendable.

perennial.meaning_1: adjective: lasting an indefinitely long time; eternal; everlasting
perennial.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
perennial.sentence_1: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.

derisive.meaning_1: adjective: abusing vocally; expressing contempt or ridicule
derisive.sentence_1: I was surprised by her derisive tone; usually, she is sweet, soft spoken, and congenial.

pertinent.meaning_1: adjective: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand
pertinent.sentence_1: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays the best on the field.

spurn.sentence_1: She spurned all his flattery and proposals, and so he walked off embarrassed and sad.

banish.meaning_1: verb: expel from a community, residence, or location; drive away
banish.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
banish.sentence_1: The most difficult part of the fast was banishing thoughts of food.

perpetuate.sentence_1: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

illicit.meaning_1: adjective: contrary to or forbidden by law
illicit.sentence_1: Though Al Capone was engaged in many illicit activities, he was finally arrested for income tax evasion, a relatively minor offense.

genteel.meaning_1: adjective: marked by refinement in taste and manners
genteel.sentence_1: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.

jargon.meaning_1: noun: a characteristic language of a particular group
jargon.sentence_1: To those with little training in medicine, the jargon of doctors can be very difficult to understand.

debase.meaning_1: verb: reduce the quality or value of something
debase.sentence_1: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.

credence.sentence_1: He placed no credence in psychics, claiming that they offered no special powers beyond the ability to make people part with their money.

buck.sentence_1: The profits at our firm bucked the general downturn that affected the real estate industry.

martial.meaning_1: adjective: suggesting war or military life
martial.sentence_1: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

tumult.meaning_1: noun: a state of chaos, noise and confusion
tumult.sentence_1: Riots broke out just in front of our apartment building, and the tumult continued late into the night.

contemptuous.meaning_1: adjective: scornful, looking down at others with a sneering attitude
contemptuous.sentence_1: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.

assuage.meaning_1: verb: make something intense less severe
assuage.sentence_1: Her fear that the new college would be filled with unknown faces was assuaged when she recognized her childhood friend standing in line.

pristine.sentence_2: Drill sergeants are known for demanding pristine cabinets, uniforms, and beds, and often make new recruits clean and clean and clean until they meet the expected high standards.
pristine.sentence_1: The glacial lake was pristine and we filled our canteens to drink deeply.

altruism.meaning_1: noun: the quality of unselfish concern for the welfare of others
altruism.sentence_1: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.

cornucopia.meaning_1: noun: an abundant supply of something good
cornucopia.sentence_1: The International Food Expo was a cornucopia of culinary delights: gourmet foods from every continent were under one roof.

rankle.meaning_1: verb: gnaw into; make resentful or angry
rankle.sentence_1: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.

glib.meaning_1: adjective: (of a person) speaking with ease but without sincerity
glib.sentence_1: I have found that the more glib the salesman, the worse the product.

unruly.meaning_1: adjective: (of persons) noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline; unwilling to submit to authority
unruly.sentence_1: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene—unless it's nap time.

uncompromising.sentence_1: The relationship between Bart and Hilda ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising, never wanting to change their opinions.
